text: Ok so this review maybe half ass but that's all I got in the short time of going through this hotel. The only reason that I entered this place was because I saw the roller coaster on top from the strip and I'm a HUGE roller coaster fan(I mean if there's a coaster I'm gonna ride it, maybe twice in a row). The outside of the hotel kind of resembles the NYC skyline, which is cool to take a pic in front of across the street. Once I entered making my way to the coaster, the place just looked like most of the other budget friend hotels around the strip(slot machines and old retired folks). Finally made our way to the coaster and it was pretty decent, smooth with good amounts of turn and loops but nothing mind blowing. Definitely worth a ride if on the strip. But then again I'm more of a fan of the wooden coasters!

I was so excited that this place finally opened the second time my hubs and I came around. Since my BIL had never been to Vegas, I was even more excited to go on L. We ended up buying tickets outside of Flamingo and ended up getting lost. But once we made it to the right location, we had no issues getting in or had to wait very long. They do offer a drink bar and restrooms prior to you getting on the pod. \nI really liked the fact that they don't try and squeeze too many people into a pod and the small seating areas on the ends of the pod. I would have to say almost everyone inside stayed standing and were busy taking pictures. \nOnce you get inside, they have a video playing while you go around and at various times, they will let you know how high you are. I didn't realize this before, but the tickets for L, does increase depending on what time of day you are going to go on it. We paid a little over $30 per person...so it does it pricey! But it's definitely a cool sight to see during sunset and worth it if you've never been that high and want to see everything.

I'm in a giant pod in the sky! I actually had a dream I was riding this one night before it opened... We got to ride before they officially opened! Hunnie Bunnie was thrilled she got to finally ride it AND ride it before her cousin! 
DEFINITELY wait to go at night time so you can see all of the pretty lights over the Valley! Not even worth it during the day.
Before you get on they take your photo which has different backgrounds for you to choose from after your ride. 
In the waiting area you can purchase cocktails. 
There are benches inside the pod, but otherwise there is plenty of standing room and room to walk around.
There is music and there are TV monitors but nothing was playing when we were riding. 
I think my one ride will be enough for my life.

Fun and relaxing with a great view, but super pricey! (Then again what in Vegas is not pricey!) During the day the ride costs about $25 per person (don't know how much it is for a child). During the night, the ride costs about $35 per person (again I don't know how much a child costs).  It takes about 30 minutes to go around in 1 full circle and you only ride it once. The ride is very very very slow and takes you up to 550 feet up in the sky. It is very high up in the sky, but the view is gorgeous.  Take lots of photo.  When I rode it there were only 12 of us inside one of the pods but I believe it can fit up to 30 people per pod and I think there are more than a dozen pods. (Don't remember...didn't count how many pods there were.)\n\nOne thing that was confusing was the lady who sold us the ticket (she was standing midway on the sidewalk of the Linq) said we could take drinks and things to eat inside. So on the way to board the ride there was a Sprinkles cupcake and ice cream store. We went in and  bought ice cream for each of us and when we tried to enter the building for the ride, a gentleman said no food allowed inside. So we had to quickly eat our ice cream to board the ride on time. Lucky us it was not busy that day and we bought tickets that gave us a 20 minute window to walk casually and buy Sprinkles ice cream (and eat it).  The only thing you can take on the ride is a drink (alcoholic/non-alcholic) that you buy from them once you pass the checkpoint and are on the second floor.

This observation wheel was high on my list of things to do this trip to Vegas. I romanticized the view of the city in my head but the actual experience fell short. I couldn't find the hours online but we arrived on a Tuesday night about 11:30pm. They informed us that the last riders would have to be on the wheel by 12. After paying nearly $80 for our two tickets, a quick trip to a really dirty bathroom (isn't this place brand new?!?) and getting a free drink (I found a text code in the taxi cab interactive TV on the way over) we walked up to the landing where you get in the pods. There were four in our party and another three people paired with us. I'm not sure why though since there was several open pods that we could have each been in by ourselves (there were about 10 people in the other pod so I guess I shouldn't complain). Entering the pod is interesting as it never stops and once inside, they lock you in adn there are two benches on either side that allow you to sit down. The pod was clean and luckily the windows were too. As other's have mentioned, there is a guide up on the screen and I can't say he added to the experience. As we climbed and reach the top, the view was anticlimactic. Last year we had dinner at the Stratosphere and that view is better! And for another $70, you can have a great dinner! Overall I can't say I regret going but I definitely wouldn't go again.

A couple weeks before our trip to Vegas, out of the blue we were wondering where the highest Ferris wheel in the world is (I am a huge Ferris wheel fan). Imagine my delight when I found out it had newly opened on the Strip! I had to do a little convincing because my partner doesn't love heights, but the fact that the viewing capsule is all enclosed made a big difference. We got tickets for nighttime because we wanted to see the lights, and it was awesome. We even saw the Bellagio fountain from the top of the wheel! Unfortunately, we had to share our capsule with some really drunk obnoxious dudes. That's really the only drawback. Overall a beautiful experience and a great way to see the lights of Vegas. It's definitely a little pricey, but the experience is worth it.

If this is your first time in Vegas, or you've never had the opportunity to see the view from high up in Vegas, then this might be worth experiencing. Otherwise, it was just...fine. The Linq is a pretty cool place, all in all, and the High Roller is a nice enough experience. It takes you in a \"pod\"- basically a large, glass enclosed room (pretty chilly, as the AC was blasting), and slowly circles so you can see some nice views of the city. We must have hit it at just the right time- 8p on a Friday- because there was absolutely no line. You have the opportunity to purchase overpriced beverages at a bar before entering into your pod, and you're off. The pod plays music (it is at a low volume, it isn't a party), and facts about Vegas. While the views are nice, it is a little on the boring side. I could see it maybe being more exciting if it were more crowded with wild people, though!   I can't see doing this over and over, but I'm glad I can check it off the list.

We went to ride the High Roller on Tuesday, June 17th at around 11 pm. We were stuck in the pod for about 20 minutes because the entire attraction stopped working. We were 2 pods away from the very top. Instead of doing a full rotation we had to go down the same way we went up. Apparently this was the first time the high roller had stopped working. The views were amazing, but the experience was not the best. When we went to the customer service desk they asked if we wanted a ticket for another day or a refund. Of course we chose the refund of $72+ for two people.

My friend got me a ticket to High Roller which he got for $17. I can count with 1 hand how many times I've been on a ferris wheel. It's a 550ft tall observation deck. You can go to Stratosphere if you want to be up higher...and jump off 858ft!

Going in the pod could be a little bit tricky if the people in front of you are scared, too slow or aren't alert...making the pod seem to be moving faster. Once you're in, the wheel moves ever so slowly and it stops. It takes 20-30 minutes to complete a whole rotation. You can either sit or stand and enjoy the view. I can see tourists enjoying this a lot.

I wish there was a way to have a pod with screaming kids and their guardians grouped together and those who don't have their own pod. Otherwise, it just turns out to be a torturous and the longest 30 minutes of your life. I'll bring Advil and earplugs next time.

Wow! What a view!

Not really sure what to say here except that this is a must do when going to Vegas.

It is the highest observation wheel in the world, 107 feet higher than the one in London. We went at night and the view was absolutely amazing. One of my friends had to get talked into going as he wasn't sure if it would be worth it. Afterwards he thanked us repeatedly for talking him into it and talked about it the rest of the trip.

It is more expensive at night, and probably at little overpriced at $35 (plus tax) but I don't regret it at all. I understand that you can get discounts if you stay at the Quad or another hotel (but not all Harrah's hotels) and they regularly have Groupon deals, so keep your eyes open.

It is cheaper during the day, but go at night, trust me!

Some important things to know:

1 - it takes 30 minutes to get all the way around, not including the wait in line if it is busy.
2 - there are no bathrooms in the pods, so tinkle before you go.
3 - there are 2 benches in the pods, but you won't want to sit down.
4 - if you time it correctly you can see the fountains at the Bellagio and it is awesome!
5 - the pods can accommodate up to 40 people so your whole group can get in the same pod. If you go during the off hours (we went after 11pm) they put fewer people in each pod which is nice.

If you are reading these reviews you are thinking about going. Stop thinking and just do it!

The High Roller allows you (and friends/family/strangers depending on who you get in a pod with) 30-minutes of scenic views of the Las Vegas Strip and the Las Vegas Valley.

Enjoy pointing out beautifully-lit casinos, marvel at the pods below and above you. Have a dance party to some of the music, or just chill on one of the benches provided. Each pod supposedly holds 40 people. I counted how many were in mine and there was 28. I would not have liked 12 more people in that thing with me.

Don't miss out on taking a look at the valley instead of the Strip, and definitely take a look at the helicopters and planes flying around pretty much where you happen to be, up in the air!

Locals get a discount, and if you buy online you can reserve a time. Skip the line to buy tickets, get a drink at the bar - and head through the many queues they have set up. We were there on a Saturday and we waited probably only about 6 minutes to get on.

Overall - a decent experience, one to do just to say you've done it.

Apparently these people don't like when you call it a "ferris wheel"... but that's exactly what it looks like! Sorry, I mean the "high roller".

Takes about 30 minutes to go around and come down. Before we got to the top, I already wanted to get off. At the top, it stops for a few minutes so you can enjoy the view, which is pretty nice, but I don't need to stare at the view for 30 minutes. They play music in the pods and the lights change colors. I think it looks more fun than it really is. 

PRICING: It's pretty, but I wouldn't pay $35. Just go to the rooftop of a hotel and enjoy that same view. It's cheaper to go during the day, but I have no idea why anyone would want to see the view then.

For some reason I was expecting this to be a cross-breed of a ferris wheel and a roller coaster and its pretty much neither. It's simply an observation pod that goes in ONE circle. 

Cons- 
-You don't really get to choose the people you ride with. You are loaded on with about 15 ppl per pod. 
-Not enough seating, its two little sitting areas on each side of the pod and it fits about 4 people on each side.  I am sure you don't want to sit the entire time but if you do its best to gets a seat facing the loading zone. Everything behind the High Roller is vacant all the lights are in the direction facing where you are loaded on. 
-Photographs will suck! Unless you're taking pics of the scenery with no flash, the reflective glass won't allow you to capture cute photos. I tried a couple of selfies but it's really dark in there and turning on the flash will just light up the whole pod and you still get the window glares in your picture. 

Pros- 
-You can drink while you are on the pod. Drinks can be purchased on your way up towards the loading area. 
-The pods are air conditioned. I am sure during the day it could get unbearably hot so luckily enough it's pretty chilly in the pods. 

One cool feature is if you pay an extra $10 ($44.95 for night time) then you can get the Happy Hour ride where you and your friends get open bar the entire 30 mins of the trip. This seems like the only option one should choose seeing as most of the time you are just idly waiting for the pod to hit the highest point. I think that could be fun with a bunch of friends but it is a bit pricey for just 10 mins of drinks. 

I did like the photo option but it comes out the blue right before the loading area so be on the lookout.

Love the High Roller, it's conveniently located and fairly affordable for how long the ride is. I wouldn't say it's \"the best\" view in Vegas but it's definitely a unique view from very high up. The ride took around 30 minutes (if I'm remembering correctly). They have their own bar priced around the same as any bar in the nearby vicinity. You ride with around 6-8 other people but the pods you ride in are huge, the only time I remember wanting a bit more space was at the very top when everybody wanted a photo of the one corner with the best view. I went on a Thursday night during EDC week (late June) and we only had to wait around 10 minutes to ride. Tickets are very easily purchased at the electronic kiosks but CHECK GROUPON or online deal sites before going. 4 stars rather than 5 because while it is affordable they kind of mess with you on the pricing... it's the same price for 4 people vs. 3 but the kiosk doesn't mention that...

Definitely a must visit for Las Vegas.  The high roller was a very fun and cool experience especially since my friends and I got a whole observation pod to ourselves.  \nMake sure you and your party is ready to hop on cause the wheel is moving continuously and you don't want to leave someone behind.  The pod is quiet spacious with 2 benches on each side and surrounded by windows for you to see the views.  The upper section of the pod has monitors that tell you how high up you are and when you get to the top.  Plenty of great views no matter where you are on the wheel.  We went during the day and it was still a great experience, but next time, I want to go at night.  \nAs I mentioned, we did get the whole pod to ourselves but we went around 5PM then walked around the Linq for a bit and saw the line for it did get really long around 7.  Overall, highly recommended.  They even have a happy hour ticket where you can open bar on the pod.

I'm not going to tell you the specifications of the High Roller since most reviews already have told you that the 550 foot observation wheel is currently the tallest in the world.
I recommend riding at night versus the day since you really get to see a stunning view of the entire Las Vegas Valley. For the people that love airplanes, at night you can see the landing and take-off patterns into and out of McCarran.

Before going, check if Groupon or Amazon Local has a ticket deal.

Also if you have a Platinum, Diamond, or Seven Stars Total Rewards card, be sure to first stop at the Concierge Desk.  Depending on your card level, you may be entitled to a larger discount or free tickets.

A word of advice for locals:  Present your Nevada ID and you get a $5 discount.

This afternoon I went on the High Roller, which is the world's tallest observation wheel.

The High Roller is a 550-foot tall giant ferris wheel. The wheel began construction in 2011 and opened in March 2014. The High Roller features 28 spherical passenger cabins which can accommodate up to 40 passengers each and is illuminated with dynamic multicolored LED lights nightly.

It cost $25 for the 30 minute ride.  You can spend an extra $5 and go in the happy hour cabin where you can drink all you want (I passed).

There were just three of us in our cabin.  The views were great!

The cabins don't stop ... you get on as it's moving.  There is a net underneath in case you misstep.

It was fun and a great way to see the city.

Went on a Thursday night and only had our group of 5 and another couple in our pod, so had plenty of room to walk around.  One person in our group had a cane and they offered to slow the pod down even further for him to get on.  Great customer service right there.  They had a ladies night special for $19.99 which included a night ride and two cocktails.  Pretty good value.  Even though I live in Vegas I enjoyed the ride.  It was nice seeing the Bellagio fountain go off.

Thoroughly enjoyed the 30 minute ride with my husband. We went on Tuesday night so there was no line and we only had 8 people in our Pod.  We got a $5 discount from a coupon book I picked up. The view of Las Vegas was amazing but you really can't take any real good pictures  from inside because of the glare.
I personally would not wait if they had a real long line. 
One thing I don't recommended is buying drinks in their bar unless you like to pay a lot for hardly any alcohol in your drink. For an extra $10 you can get a pod that serves you all the booze you can drink in 30 minutes but I am not exactly sure what that means so be sure to ask for specifics. There is no restroom in the pods so that could turn out to the a really bad idea.
When you get of your ride you get sent right through their gift store on your way out.

The High Roller holds the Guiness World record for being the tallest Observation Wheel. It is 550 feet with 28 pods that holds upto 40people. My friends and I went there on a Tuesday. They had half off tickets for the local. One of my friends told us to go right at sunset for the best view and low and behold he was right. The 30 mins ride went by so quick as we observed the panoramic view, conversed, took bunch of pictures. Every minute the color of the sky changes with the Bellagio fountain turned on. It was a breathtaking view. The movement is slow and the height was not scary at all to me. As it was descending, I heard one of my friend say \" is that Mindy from Mindy Project?\" Sure enough it was her, she was about to get on the Pod. She was being photographed and the bar was rolled inside the Pod. Later found out it was her indeed and it was her birthday and she was there with another female celebrity. We had a fabulous time!

The ride is so boring.  You can technically book a hotel room facing the strip and request for the room at the top of their building and have the same view for probably cheaper.  Whatever you do, don't purchase the VIP package, especially by using Travelzoo's coupon code.  Terrible deal ( http://www.travelzoo.com/entertainment/las-vegas/-63-High-Roller-VIP-Ride-Package-for-Two-1871376/?conf=1&cm=signedin&source=_tzlock&placement=Overlay-TravelDeal-DealPage-SignUpFP5), especially if you are going to ride this ride before 7pm (day time cut off) since the day pass is only 24.99$/per person (that's 50$ for 2 instead of 63$ for two) If you're thinking that it comes with free drinks and photos with this package, it doesn't.  They made me pay for those things and when I told them that my ticket and this thing says it's complimentary, they told me to contact Travelzoo or Linq's itself.  I will post pictures later to show you the receipt I paid for for the extra items listed here. You're basically paying for more to ride this boring ride and for the coupons.  Oh, and also, that deal from Travelzoo can only be purchased on a computer and not a mobile device--I didn't know that so wasted so much time calling them (they kept bouncing me around from one to another, from Linq's itself and Travelzoo agents, instead of just telling me that) and trying to enter it with different Internet browser as they advised it. And when I did it on a computer, Linq's website was down, so I didn't know that it would only work with a computer till I had my friend test it out for me a few days later while I was on the rode driving to Vegas.  Seriously, save your money and go ziplining or ride on their roller coasters or do a tour or something there instead.

A-OK. We got a living social deal for a ride on the High Roller and a drink up to the value of $9 for $18 each, It was a few more dollars for the night time ride, We turned up showed our ticket and went to get a drink from the bar, the whole building was pretty cool! A bit like a theme park queue at Disneyland, then it was time to board our pod, i think we got lucky as there was a huge party before us who all got in one pod together then we were next and we were in a pod with only a few others so i think its all pot luck on what time you go, The whole ride takes around 30 minutes with a pretty annoying video commentary of some annoying guy, The pods are quite large with plastic hard seating in places around the pod, but you do get a 360 degree view of Las Vegas through the big windows around the pod, Unfortunatly though the view isn't all that great, all you get to see is the back of the Hotels,the mountains in the distance  and the Airport,  and we got a better view from our hotel at the Cosmopolitan. Though it was cool to go on the tallest observation wheel in the world at a staggering 550ft!!!

Enjoyable half hour-ish trip over the Vegas Strip in a pod on a giant Ferris wheel. You get some great views of the strip and beyond. The pod is totally enclosed and when I went on a weekday afternoon there were only six of us in the pod so it wasn't too crowded either. I don't like heights but had zero problems on this since it felt more like being in a building than an open Ferris wheel car. The host in the automated tour video is annoying (tries to be funny and is an epic fail) and we'd have muted him had we been given the choice. 

Try to get a living social deal to get a lot of money off and a free alcoholic drink up to $10 at the bar before you enter the pod. Be warned there is no bathroom on the pod but there is one before you board. Also, the pod doesn't totally stop when you enter and exit so be careful.

This is a unique view of Vegas and something that I'd recommend whether you're new to Vegas or a regular visitor. Not sure I'd do it again during the day but maybe I'd check it out at night.

Move over Singapore Flyer! You are no longer the tallest observation wheel in the world!   The High Roller at The Linq in Las Vegas is!

Nestled behind The Imperial Palace, er I mean, The Linq is a giant wheel of metal and glass bubbles that does one rotation inside of 30 minutes!

My gf and I were lucky that our timing was impeccable because we arrived when one of the pods was almost out of entrance range, that there was only one other couple inside it.  Unlike the other pods where there were more than 6-8 people inside!  It is almost as if we had the pod to ourselves, almost!

While the overall environment controlled cabin was pleasent, the seating could have been improved by using padded seats instead of the hard, sterile plastic that awaited our butts! Not that it mattered too, too much as you would find yourself standing most of the time in this ride marveling at the bright Vegas strip lights below! 

What is definitely sorely needed is a way to disable the annoying infomercial playing on the screen inside the cabin.  The host of the informative show was tolerable the first 5 minutes, but a whole 30 minutes of badly scripted jokes and anecdotes,  one has had enough crass!   Perhaps there should be a way to switch to a radio station, or to satellite radio playing music instead?

The High Roller is best experienced during night time, or at dusk. Although, I wouldn't mind going during the day if the oppportunity came up.  

The selections at the pre-boarding bar could be a little bit better, as it was quite pricy.  Like most tourist attractions, you can't bring your own food or drinks, even if it is Vegas where one could get intoxicated on the strip itself!

Happy high rolling!

Warning:  Do not waste your money!   This was the most boring ride!  I would not do again even if it was free!   Of course it was expensive.  We went after 6pm when it is $35/adult.  Luckily the night we were it was "ladies night" so my ticket was just $19.  Thankfully, kids under 12 are free so the damage could have been much worse.

There was about a ten minute wait to buy tickets and then a 10-15 minute wait to get into our "pod".  The pod is large and could probably fit 40 people.  Our pod was nice and roomy with only about 20 people inside.  There was plenty of room to move about and take pictures.  But take pictures of what?  Until the pod gets up to the top there is not much of a view.  Even when you do get to the top, you get to see lights and hotels.  I just really did not find those sights to be very interesting or exciting.  This activity was weak for the kids as well. They though it would be like a gigantic ferris wheel but they were greatly disappointed.  

I noticed some other reviewers complained about the "lame video". I actually found the video to be moderately entertaining because there was nothing else to do!  I could not even Yelp as my phone battery was dying!

I know this is Vegas and I don't mind paying the high Vegas prices for an activity that is enjoyable.  This is not one of those activities. The only thing High Roller would be good for is as a substitute for a sleeping pill!

The view was nice. We purchased a Groupon for the open bar option. It may have saved money? But it was not worth it. Our pod was full, so the half hour ride amounted to getting ONE drink. It was either that or wait in line for the one bartender and miss all the views. It was pretty dead that night. It would have been nice if our group of 8 could have had our own ride to ourselves. Then it would have been worth it!

High in the sky at 550 feet In the air! Taking a ride on the giant temperature controlled observation wheel with floor to ceiling windows is pricey, but the views of the city are breathtaking.

I bought a Groupon deal for $69 for VIP ride package for 2, plus 2-for-1 souvenir drinks and 15% off 1 regularly priced item or photo in the sky retail shop. The Groupon was a great deal for the ride for 2 and BOGO souvenir drink. We passed on purchasing the souvenir photo since it looked super cheesy and photoshopped.

We tried to get there in time for a sunset ride, but there was a line and also a brief boarding wait, so we missed it. I quickly forgot my disappointment when we saw the glimmering lights of the strip and the city from above. The evening views though! The city lights twinkling at night are gorgeous and give you butterflies in your stomach.

It takes 30 minutes to complete a full revolution during which you get an eagle-eyed view of The Strip and beyond. The strip view was our favorite, but we did also enjoy panoramic views of the rest of the city. If you are a Vegas local, this experience is a perfect way to appreciate the jazzy city and beautiful desert topography you live in. 

Forty people can fit into a single observation pod, but they do a pretty good job of not stuffing the pods so that you have room to comfortably move about the space. On our trip there were less than 15 people in the spacious pod. 

Just remember that ticket prices increase after 7pm (because the views and lights of the city are better at night)

Of course make sure to take lots of pictures, but remember to take the time to be in the moment with your loved ones and enjoy the experience! It's a memorable journey to the top! 

Side note: our TV host (television spokesperson of the ride) was totally corny. Let's just say #90sgameshowhostwannabe. The music selection was mainly top 40's and also very cliche but I suppose it makes the trip a little more lighthearted and eases nerves for people who have the fear of heights.

I hate to say it, but a giant Ferris wheel ride overlooking a city used to be a novelty, but with more and more of them being built, they are becoming a one and done type deal. 

Having ridden the London Eye, the High Roller, is a nice knock off that has made some improvements, especially on the pod design.

Price:

Pricing varies. There are a handful of options, i.e. Happy Hour, Resident Discount Day, Daytime/Nighttime , etc. I would look for discount tickets and not pay full price for the experience.

View:

The view is some what boring. I wouldn't say that you have the best view of the strip as it is off back by the monorail a little ways from the Flamingo. I felt that you get better views if you visit Paris' Eiffel Tower

Pod:

The pod does have two benches to sit, but the number of seats are limited. Depending on who your with, as the can hold 20+ people, it can feel tight and the people you are with can be a bit of a pain to deal with for 30+ minutes. You are also held captive to the stupid video with an annoying host. Some of the facts are interesting, but there is no mute button.


Tips:

- Best spot to stand for the best view is once you enter, is on the right side near where you enter the pod

-Tune your flash off on you camera/phone, and if after the ump-tenth time your picture ends up blurry, you might just want to give up and enjoy the ride

- Go to the bathroom prior to getting in line. They do have a small one behind the drink counter prior to entering the ticket scanning line.
